In 5r.a.10, le lezioni greche 'edein' seguito da 'eidein', e anche 'plion' seguito da 'pleion' sono da discutere in una complicata discussione critico-testuale, anche in considerazione dei testimoni del testo di Prisciano (vd. app. crit. di Keil K.2.71.11). Tra l'altro, dovrei riportare il testo dei testimoni del testo di Prisciano nella nota contenutistica a quel punto [P.S.: ma forse l'ho già fatto].

I always put a space at the end of the lb, cb, pb elements (XHTML-style). I am afraid that this is not the TEI-style, and that TEI has no space at the end of such elements: if so, delete it from this file, from vimrc and from the paoloMarkDown.py script.

Filologia testuale: 'quoniam' (parola con id w18300) mi pare strano (nonostante l'abbreviazione di solito significhi proprio 'quoniam'). La fonte (Prisc. Ars K.2.78.20) ha 'quia' che introduce un'oggettiva. Ma può 'quoniam' introdurre oggettive? O lo scriba ha frainteso 'quia' pensandolo introduttore di causale? Lo stesso nella parola con id w36645: in questo caso Prisciano K.2.129.22 ha "quod".

I added 'milestone' elements for long sources only for the final part of the transcription. I could add them for the initial part too. Also, I'm not rendering those milestones in any way: I could think of a possible rendering.

For clear 'scribal error[s]', I sometimes correct in the value of @n, sometimes do not. Also, sometimes I insert a @type="script" note, sometimes a @type="content" note. I normally use 'script' when I correct silently, 'content' when I do not. This only is to check until the first note with type "emendation".

Specifica i type di 'note' con i due nuovi tipi 'emendation' e 'graphic'. Ricomincia dalla parola w28905 andando a ritroso.

Per le attuali 'note' @type="emendation", usa 'corr' (oppure 'supplied') con solo il livello linguistico ('w' vuoto con attributi), secondo quanto dice file:///usr/share/doc/tei-p5-doc/en/html/ref-add.html nel paragrafetto 'Note'. Potrei usare la coppia sic/corr come in http://www.tei-c.org/release/doc/tei-p5-doc/en/html/CO.html#COEDCOR per gli errori evidenti. In http://www.tei-c.org/release/doc/tei-p5-doc/en/html/PH.html#PHCC si parla di emendazioni più congetturali, e c'è un paragrafo interessante (find 'In addition, the conscientious encoder will provide documentation explaining the circumstances') in cui dice che potrei inserire in un elemento correction dentro la encodingDesc dettagli sui valori dell'elemento @type di corr.
Potrei usare 'gap' per unclear @type="cropped", ma probabilmente è meglio di no. Attualmente ho usato 'unclear' e aggiunto un 'note' @type="script".
Gestisci meglio i 'pc' type=quote

Problema di visualizzazione: quando inserisco un segno di punteggiatura a livello AL/LL non corrispondente ad alcun segno sul manoscritto, nel browser comunque spunta nella riga GL uno spazio. Potrei usare [pc n="."] [/pc] (cioè uno spazio al GL che 'significa' un punto al LL).

ab.n: Introduction to the parts of speech

ref.note: For section ab06 Morelli 1910, 291 mentions the following sources: "Donato K. IV. 372 25 sgg. e commentatori di Donato; Prisc. 54 segg." Donatus and Priscianus are imitated quite loosely in this section. I should inquire better about the commentaries on Donatus though. More specific imitations on Priscianus included in this section are referenced directly here. Possible comments on Donatus might include: (A) Seruius, K.4.405-K.4.448. For example K.5.81-K.5.312 and in particular on the parts of speech K.5.134 ff.

ref.w: aer Note that since here "ae" is no diphthong, it is written with two separate graphemes "a" and "e".

ref.note: Morelli 1910, p. 291, n. 3 corrects "inpura" to "in pure" and comments: "Cod. inpura. Correggo secondo la fonte di Ursus, Virg. gramm. p. 85,23 Huemer: "Pus in philosophia custodia dicitur, ut ait Origenes: Positis in pure fratribus solus evasit".

ab.n: Another definition and etymology of nomen

ref.w: nomaOn the linguistic layer (LL), this word will not be able to be processed by a parser, as it does not exist in common dictionaries. Priscianus means this to be a previous (no longer existing) form of the word ὄνομα.

add.note: This is an explanatory interlinear glossa. In the mansucript, it is linked to the main text by means of a cross sign between "nascitur" and "ut". The text in the glossa is closer to the text of Priscianus (the source of this passage).

ref.w: athomas In his edition of Priscian, Ars grammatica K.2.58.26, the source of this passage, Keil corrects the reading "atoma" of all manuscripts to "atomos", which does agree with the previous "quas" because Latin substantive "atomus (or atomos), - i" (like Greek "ἡ ἄτομος") is feminine. Keil's apparatus says that Priscian's manuscripts BGKL have "quae... atoma" (neuter). For the other manuscripts with "atoma", i.e. for P and H, Keil's apparatus does not mention any variant to "quas", so I am assuming that P and H have "quas... atoma". As far as Ursus is concerned, however, he often uses Greek words (in Latin transliteration) for grammatical concepts. Compare Morelli 1911, 290 on this: "Ursus aggiunge anche, dicemmo, qualcosa di suo: che non è però molto notevole. Una certa conoscenza della lingua greca, diffusa nella regione cassinese e beneventana specialmente per merito di Paolo Diacono, non gli doveva mancare; egli ne fa simpatica ostentazione, non mancando mai di aggiungere alle denominazioni grammaticali latine le corrispondenti denominazioni greche, e diffondendosi a parlare delle relazioni fra declinazione latina e declinazione greca". So I believe that the scribe here means to write the Greek version of the word (though, as usual, in Latin transliteration), and therefore he uses the Greek "-ας" ending. I encoded the word as such at the Linguistic Layer. If this is the case, the only scribal error is in the spelling ("th" for "t": a very easily explainable error).

pu
plius The classical spelling of this name is "Publius", and Keil publishes it as such, though he mentions in his apparatus note to Priscianus, Ars grammatica K.2.57.19 that Priscian's manuscripts GLK have "puplius" too. So I am unsure whether I should really emend the "Puplius" spelling to classical "Publius" (as I am doing in the encoding of the Linguistic Layer) or not, here and elsewhere in the manuscript text.

ref.note: Verg. Aen. 5.407 has "magnanimusque Anchisiades". Note the different spelling: Vergil has "Anchisiades", Ursus "Anchisades". Both spellings occur in the manuscript: "Anchisiades" is found twice, in 4r.b.20 (folio 4r, column b, line 20) and in 4v.a.2. "Anchisades" is found here and in 4v.a.1, so I woul not emend this reading in "Anchisiades".

Morelli 1910, p. 292 writes that this passage has no source: "haec autem nomina ueniunt a futuris infiniti, mutata tum in men, ut prenotum ire prenomen, notum ire nomen, cognitum ire cognomen, agnitum ire agnomen".

w.note: This grapheme looks like a "p" with both a bottom-left tail (which would make it a "ŋ" grapheme, abbreviation for "pro") and a horizontal dash crossing the descending trait (which would make it a "þ" grapheme, abbreviation for "per"). Probably the same hand first wrote the abbreviation for "per", than changed his mind and added the bottom-left tail that made it an abbreviation for "pro".

ref.w: xxxiiii The source, Priscian, Ars grammatica, K.2.59.9, does not mention the number of the species, but simply writes: "Appellatiuorum multae sunt species".

ref.w: synonima The initial "s" is written with black ink.

gentile The initial "g" is written in black ink. It is apparent here that the first hand (writing in brown ink) had written this "g" with its regular shape and size, and the second hand (writing in black ink) derased the original "g" and wrote it over the rasura with a larger grapheme in uncial script. All initial graphemes of words denoting a "species" of appellatiuum nomen in lines 31-35 are in black ink. Some of them are clearly written in rasura.

relatiua The larger initial grapheme is written in black ink over a rasura (same situation as "gentile" above).
patronomica I am encoding the classical spelling "patronymica" at the Linguistic Layer. The source Priscianus, Ars grammatica K.2.60.2 has "patronymicum".

uerbialis The direct source, Priscian, Ars grammatica K.2.60.4 has "uerbalia". The form "uerbialia" is in Pompeius, "Commentum Artis Donati", K.5.149.1. Lewis-Short has a lemma "uerbialis, e, adf.", but reports Pompeius as the only example. Based on a search on the PHI 5.3 corpus with Diogenes 3.2.0, the adjective does never occur in classical Latin.

w.note: This allograph of the "÷" grapheme (logograph for "est") has a comma-like sign below the horizonta line and a regular dot above that line.

ref.note: For "acies ferri", see Plin., Naturalis Historia, 7.64.5: "acies ferri praestringitur" (from the same work, also see 7.63.3: "ea est caro informis, inanima, ferri ictum et aciem respuens"; 13.142.7: "sentire eum se capi durarique cornus modo et hebetare aciem ferri" 19.11.4: "ferri aciem vincunt"; 27.10.5: "quae cotibus in ferri acie deterenda"; 34.144.3: "nucleusque quidam ferri excoquitur in iis ad indurandam aciem"; 34.145.4: "neque alia genera ferri ex mera acie temperantur"; 34.154.1: "squama quoque ferri in usu est ex acie aut mucronibus".
ref.w: gradibus In the fourth position ("graDibus") two graphemes (a "u" and a "d") are overwritten one above the other. Also in the sixth position ("gradiBus"), two graphemes are overwritten (a "b" and a "d"). Obviously a second hand corrected the original graphemes of the first hand in these positions. I think that the source that the author was drawing from had "gradiuus" (the common epithet for Mars), which is the reading that I am restoring at the Linguistic Layer. One hypothesis is that the first hand wrote "grauidus" and the second corrected to "gradibus", which is in its turn a misspelling for "gradiuus" (with the very common scribal error "b for u", due to the scribe's pronunciation of "b"). A second hypothesis is the the first hand wrote "gradibus" and the second hand, not understand that it was a misspelled form of "gradiuus", mistakingly corrected it to the common adjective "grauidus".

Strangely enough, "em" here is abbreviated with "e caudatum" and the "2" abbreviation sign. Also, while we tend to write "quemadmodum" as one word, and as such I am encoding it at the Lingustic Layer, the scribe spells it as two words, with a graphical space in between: "quem" "admodum". In consideration of the fact that the scribe often writes "ad" with no space after it, it might also be that the scribe is writing this expression as three separate words: "quem", "ad" and "modum".

dictum As the grammatical subject is "quae", this should be "dicta est". The source (Priscian, Ars grammatica, 2.60.19) has: "Ad aliquid dictum est, quod sine intellectu illius, ad quod dictum est, proferri non potest". So in that case the pronominal subnect is "quod" and the verb agreement is correctly "dictum est".

ref.note: "Spanus a Spanis" is probably a scribal error for "Hispanus ab Hispanis", and I am encoding these words as such at the Linguistic Layer. The source, Priscian, Ars grammatica K.2.61.3 has different examples: "Gentile est, quod gentem significat, ut 'Graecus', 'Latinus'", so it is not helpful here.
ref.w: patriæm The word, as it stands, makes no sense. The source, Priscian, Ars grammatica K.2.61.3, has "Patrium est, quod a patria sumitur, ut 'Atheniensis', 'Romanus'". The simplest emendation could be "patriae", and I am encoding this word as such at the Linguistic Layer. The emendation is likely because Ursus already wrote "gentis" (genitive) instead of Priscian's "gentile" (adjective) shortly above (in line 8 of the same page).
ref.note: Over the words "quis", "qualis", "quantus" and "quot" the scribe wrote a horizontal dash meaning their interrogative role in a sentence. Over "quotus" this sign has the shape of a French circumflex accent.

ref.w: angelus The source, Priscian, Ars grammatica, K.2.61.26 does not have this example (it has "ut 'animal', 'arbor'"). The Christian example was invented byUrsus, like this whole explanation of the "specialis species".
dicitur If the subject is "numeri", the verb agreement should require "dicuntur" here.
ref.note: For "tertiusdecimus" and "nonumdecimum", I think that the scribe meant to write the two components of each word ("tertius" and "decimus", as well as "nonum" and "decimum") separately, and I am encoding them as separate linguistic words at the Linguistic Layer.
ref.w: uicesimusThere is a macron over the "e" of "uicesimus". Macrons often mark the long quantity of a vowel, but the sentence before spoke about "accentus", so it might mark the word stress here.
decimusThere is a macron over the "c" of "decimus", that might be meant to be over the "e". For its function, see the note on "uicesimus" right before in this very line.

This is a fairly rare case in which the final ";" abbreviation mark is used to mean a final "-us" morpheme.

epimerizomena The source of this passage is Priscian "De figuris numerorum" (Keil 3.413.24) and has ἐπιμεριζόμενα. The text in this point of the manuscript is almost completely faded, especially the graphemes between "epi-" and "-omena". However, based on the number of graphemes that seem to be in this word the scribe probably wrote a shorter word than ἐπιμεριζόμενα, possibly something like "epirizomena".

ref.note: The source of this passage, Priscian "De figuris numerorum" (Keil 3.415.24-26), after "milies", has: "Infinitis tamen numerorum aduerbiis etiam n interponitur, quotiens totiens, similiter multotiens. Inueniuntur et aliae deriuationes uel compositiones multae a nominibus numerorum, ut unicus...". Probably the scribe initially skipped the sentence "Infinitis... multotiens" (line 24 in Keil) and started copying from the sentence "Inueniuntur et aliae deriuationes" (line 26 in Keil), so he wrote "inueniuntur" (which originally had the initial "i" written with a larger size). Then, he decided not to skip the sentence "Infinitis tamen numerorum..." and copied it after "inueniuntur", but he forgot to erase "inueniuntur", which remained in the manuscript as a relic. The same scribe at a later time (or someone else) then erased the large initial "i" of "inueniuntur", overwrote it in rasura with a smaller size, and also overwrote the initial "i" of "infinitis" with a larger font. As usual, I kept the the original punctuation in the Graphemic Layer and put my contemporary punctuation in the Linguistic Layer. The reason why no scribe decided to erase "inueniuntur" is probably that it could seem to belong to the previous sentence, which I do not believe. In an interpretive edition, the word "inueniuntur" shoud therefore be omitted.
ref.w: septimania The handwriting is not clear, but after the "n" there seem to be more than just an "a". If so, this is probably a scribal error ("septimania" for "septimana").

bessis Lewis-Short Latin dictionary writes that the most common nominative is "bes", but also nominative "bessis" is attested: "bes, bessis, m. (nom. bessis, Paul. ex Fest. p. 33 Müll.; Prisc. Ponder. p. 1348 P.)". Source: A Latin Dictionary. Founded on Andrews' edition of Freund's Latin dictionary. revised, enlarged, and in great part rewritten by. Charlton T. Lewis, Ph.D. and. Charles Short, LL.D. Oxford. Clarendon Press. 1879, retrieved from http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=bes&fromdoc=Perseus%3Atext%3A1999.04.0059 on June 23, 2016.
annys This is the only case in the work in which the grapheme "y" and the alphabeme "y" are meant to encode what we would today represent as a sequence of two "u" alphabemes.
uAs above, the glyph for the numeral "five" is pointy like modern "v", not rounded.
ref.note: Verg. Aen. 5.144-145 (urn:cts:latinLit:phi0690.phi003:5.144-5.145).

This passage exists only as a fragment from the indirect tradition: Claudius Caesar Germanicus, Fragmenta Aratea (The Aratus ascribed to Germanicus Caesar, ed. D. B. Gain, 1976), fragment 6 (urn:cts:latinLit:phi0881.phi002:6.1-6.2)

The phrase "de numeris" does not match with the syntax of the rest of the text. It probably is a heading, as from this point Ursus starts following a new source: Priscian, De figuris numerorum (urn:cts:latinLit:stoa0234a.stoa003).

The first hand had written "hi·et·hæ et hæc tres ettria" ("hi et hae et haec tres et tria"). A second hand deleted "et hæc" (after "et hae") and added "hæc" between "et" and "tria", thus transforming the text into what it is now: "hi et hæ tres et hæc tria" ("hi et hae tres et haec tria").

ref.note: The manuscript text is "patronymica in 'des' terminantia, si uenerint ab eisdem grecis quorum nominatiuus terminatur 'as' et genitiuus 'os' dyphthongum debent habere ante 'des' 'a' penultima breuis". My emendation of the text is: "patronymica in 'des' terminantia, si uenerint ab eisdem grecis, quorum nominatiuus terminatur [scil. in ] 'as' et genitiuus [scil. in ] 'oy' diphthongum, debent habere ante 'des' 'a' penultimam breuem" (in Greek transliteration: "terminatur [scil. in ] 'ας' et genitiuus [scil. in ] 'ου' diphthongum"). The source (Priscian, Ars grammatica, Keil 2.65.18-2.65.20) has: "Si nominatiuus Graecus in 'ας' uel in 'ης' uel 'ιος' desinat, genetiuus uero in 'ου' diphthongum, a paenultima breuis ante 'des' inuenitur in patronymico", but different branches of the textual tradition of Priscian have different Greek letters. Codex R ("cod. bibl. imp. Paris. 7496"), first and second hand: "in as (with ac written above the word) uel in es (with EC written above the word) uel os (with IOC written above the word)". Codex B ("cod. bibl. publ. Bambergensis"): "ac uel HC uel IOC". Codex b (same codex, second hand): "in ac uel ī HC uel ī IOC". Codex D ("cod. bibl. publ. Bernensis, olim Bongarsianus"): "in as uel in es uel in ios". Codex G ("cod. bibl. conventus Sangallensis"), first and second hand: "in as (with 'uel es' written above the line) uel ios". Codex K ("cod. bibl. Caroliruhensis 223"): "in ac uel IOC uel HC". Codex H ("cod. bibl. gymn. Halberstadiensis, Lutherius Krehlii"): "ac uel HC uel IOC". Codex L ("cod. bibl. publ. Lugd. Bat. olim Gruterianus"): "in as uel in os". The erroneous reading "os" (for "ου") appears only in codex R, but the "os"/"ου" error of the scribe of this manuscript might have arisen independently.
ref.w: peliades There is a macron over the "i", probably marking the quantity of the letter. A macron in the manuscript usually marks a long quantity, but in this case the quantity of both the "i" and the "a" should in fact be short. I am not encoding these quantity marks in the graphematic transcription because they do not have graphematic value, i.e. they do not create "minimal pairs" of words.
æneas There is a ^ sign over the "e" (the "e" between the "n" and the "a"), probably marking the long quantity of the letter.

priamos There is an acute accent sign over the "i", marking the quantity of the vowel, or possibly simply the stress on that syllable. I am not recording such signs because they do not have graphemic value, i.e. they do not create "minimal pairs" of words.

priamoys Scribal error: "priamoys" ("Πριάμους") for "priamoy" ("Πριάμου"). Compare the source, Priscian, Ars grammatica K.2.66.39: "Πρίαμος Πριάμου". In line 3 above the scribe wrote only two possible genitive endings for this category of nouns ("ος" and "ους"), while the source (Priscian, Ars grammatica K.2.66.37-38) has three genitive endings: "ου", "ος" and "ους". One line below (here, in line 4) the scribe gave to the genitive of Πρίαμος an erroneous ending Πριάμους (instead of the correct Πριάμους), probably also because the correct ending "ου" was not listed among the possible genitive endings in line 3.

ref.note: The Greek words I encoded at the Linguistic Layer (ᾔδην and ᾔδειν) are Keil's corrections. The original text of the Casanatensis is the one encoded at the Graphematic and Alphabetic Layers. The manuscripts of Priscianus (the source here is Priscianus K.2.71.11), as reported in Keil's apparatus criticus, often have the same (transliterated) readings as the Casanatensis. This is a fairly serious textual critical problem. Keil's apparatus note to ᾔδην has: "11 ᾔδην scripsi, cf. Eustath. ad Hom. Od. XIII 220 Sturzium de dial. Gr. p. 64 C.". As to the readings found in the manuscripts, the apparatus has: "ΗΔΗΝ H ΗΔ.ΙΝ Rr ΗΔΕ*Ν*(Ι) D ΗΔΕΝ K eden GL". For ᾔδειν, Keil's apparatus has: "ᾔδειν scripsi ΕΙΔΕΙΝ R eid*n (i) D eiden HGLK" (see http://www.unipa.it/paolo.monella/ursus/sigla.pdf for Keil's sigla codicum).

The Greek words I encoded at the Linguistic Layer (πλῆον and πλεῖον) are Keil's corrections. The original text of the Casanatensis is that encoded at the Graphematic and Alphabetic Layers. The manuscripts of Priscianus (the source here is Priscianus K.2.71.11), as reported in Keil's apparatus criticus, never have "plion", but do have "pleion". This is another fairly serious textual critical problem. This is Keil's apparatus note for πλῆον: "ΠΑΗΩΝ Rr ΠΑΗΟΝ D ΠΕΛΗΟΝ d ΠΗΛΗΩΝ GL ΠΛΗΟΝ H ΠΛΕΟΝ K". This is his note for πλεῖον: "ΠΛΕΙΟΝ ex ΠΛΕΙΙΟΝ corr. in lit. r peλeion ex ΠΕΑΑΕΙΟΝ ni f. corr. d ΠΗΛΕΙΩΝ L peleion K peion H".

The first version of the text in the manuscript was "solet conuerti ει dyphthongus [sic] in 'i' longum interpositum pro consonante", where "interpositum" was probably meant to modify "i". A second hand added the word "u" above the line, thus changing the text into "solet conuerti ει dyphthongus in 'i' longum, interpositum 'u' pro consonante", where "solet conuerti ει dyphthongus in 'i' longum" is the main clause and "interpositum 'u' pro consonante" is an accusative absolute. I think that the latter (the text of the second hand) is the best one. The source Priscian Ars Grammatica K.2.74.18 had an ablative absolute "interposita similiter u pro consonante".

w.note: This word is a very interesting use case for the encoding of abbreviations. The macron that crosses the long ascending trait of the "d" might well be interpreted as spanning not only over the "d", but also over the first grapheme. The latter, however, already is an abbreviation, since it is a "ŋ" brevigraph normally meaning "prae" (which, through monophthongation, becomes "pre"). So the first grapheme would be involved in two different abbreviations: it is a brevigraph per se, but it is also part of the abbreviation involving the whole word (marked by the macron above it). However, in my JavaScript code handling the XML/TEI code, I did not think of handling a case in which an "abbr" element is child of another "abbr" element. Also, the macron is mostly over the "d", so I am encoding this as though the macron was over the "d" only.

ref.w: isto The final "o" comes from the deletion of a previous "e".

ref.note: Who is "shown to be excellent" ("excellere ostenditur")? It might be "ipsos" (if "ostenditur" has an impersonal construction), referring back to the people ("personas", plural) mentioned shortly before. Or it might be "hic" (if "ostenditur" has a personal construction). It cannot be both. In favor of "ipsos" is the fact that the phrase "personas uel res" mentioned before is plural (like "ipsos"). Also in favor of "ipsos" might be the puctuation mark (followed by a larger initial) between "ostenditur" and "hic", however this mark should probably be ignored altogether, since "hic, cui 'ulterior' uel 'interior' adiungi uidentur" cannot be a separate main clause: if it were, subject "hic" would not be followed by any verb. In favor of "hic" is the very relative clause "cui 'ulterior' uel 'interior' adiungi uidentur" (where "cui" is singulr, therefore must have a singular antecedent). I think that the case for "hic" is stronger. If "hic" is the subject of "excellere ostenditur", then "ipsos" might be meant as a direct object of "excellere", though in classical Latin the verb does not take an accusative as direct object. My interpretation would then be: "It is shown that a specific person ('hic'), to whom 'ulterior' or 'interior' seem to be attributed, surpasses them ('ipsos')". It should be noted that this sentence is not taken from the source (Priscian Ars grammatica, K.2.86.12-16), but is an addition by Ursus, so a non-classical syntactical construction might be possible.

In classical Latin, when "oportet" has a construction with a subject in nominative, the verb is in the subjunctive mood. Compare the examples in the Perseus Lewis-Short (A Latin Dictionary. Founded on Andrews' edition of Freund's Latin dictionary. revised, enlarged, and in great part rewritten by. Charlton T. Lewis, Ph.D. and. Charles Short, LL.D. Oxford. Clarendon Press. 1879, retrieved from http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Perseus%3Atext%3A1999.04.0059%3Aentry%3Doportet on February 26, 2017): "With subj.: 'ex rerum cognitione efflorescat et redundet oportet oratio,' Cic. de Or. 1, 6, 20: 'me ipsum ames oportet, non mea,' id. Fin. 2, 26: 'valeat possessor oportet,' Hor. Ep. 1, 2, 49." Otherwise, it may be built with "ut and subjunctive" (late Latin). However, I would not emend "comparatiuus" to "comparatiuum".

The sentence does not have a subject. The final "o" of "comparatiuo" is a correction written over the original final "u" with a "2" abbreviation mark above (for "comparatiuum"). So the first hand meant "in nullo (scil. uerbo) comparatiuum (subject) i productum habet ante or". The simplest emendation of this passage would be to restore the text of the first hand: "in nullo (scil. uerbo) comparatiuum etc.". The source (Priscian Ars grammatica K.2.91.16) has: "quia in nulla comparatiuo i ante "or" produci potest".

ref.w:
ŋ pro
eliis
Interestingly, the scribe preferred using the brevigraph "ŋ" (for "pro") and then the grapheme for "e", thus preserving the diphthong, rather than reducing the diphthong "oe" to one "e" ("preliis") and using the abbreviation "p with horizontal trait" for "pre". This shows that the scribe was well aware that the classical Latin spelling included a diphthong in "proeliis".
ref.note: The source of this example is Cicero, Pro Rege Deiotaro 8, through Priscian, Ars grammatica 2.93.18. Cicero's text (in Clark's 1918 edition) is: "istam, inquam, dexteram non tam in bellis neque in proeliis quam in promissis et fide firmiorem". Priscian's text (in Keil's edition) is the same, with an variant "dextera" / "dextra" in the manuscripts.

In the relevant apparatus note, Keil writes that the reading "gigantum" is in "Prisc. cum codd. Iuv. interpolatis", that Priscian's codex P has "gigantum", Dd have "gigantium" and "Iuv. cod. Pith. et schol. ant." have "gigantis" (see http://www.unipa.it/paolo.monella/ursus/sigla.pdf for Keil's sigla codicum).

equuleus Lewis-Short's dictionary has both spelling: "equuleus" and "eculeus". The source here is Priscian, Ars grammatica K.2.102.10. Keil chooses the spelling "eculeus", of witness r, but reports that "equuleus" is the reading of manuscript L only, while witnesses Gg have "equleus" with a "u" added after "equ" in marginal position. This might provide evidence on what text of Priscian Ursus read.

The source, Priscian, Ars grammatica K.2.102.20-22 has: "nomina tertiae uel quartae uel quintae declinationis pleraque, non tamen omnia, ut quidam putauerunt, diminutiuorum masculina in "culus"...".
This is a rare case in which the "|" (comma-like) punctuation sign is used as a quotation mark for alphabemes.
ref.w: es The source Priscian, Ars grammatica K.2.103.4 has: "monosyllaba in s desinentia". So probably the scribe had the alphabeme "s" in mind. He normally used to write the grapheme "s" in these cases, but here he wrote the name of the alphabeme as it was pronounced aloud (IPA /es/), instead of the corresponding grapheme. This is why, at the Linguistic Layer, I am simply enconding "s". This is the second such case in the manuscript.

ar·ie·te Middle dots are used within this word to mark the metric scansion.
ref.note: The source of the example is Verg. Aen. 2.492: "labat ariete crebro", through Priscian, Ars grammatica K.2.106.9 (with the same text).

The word "ariete" is repeated two times in this line ("ariete crebro pro ariete"). The difference in quantity of the syllables (that makes the difference between the two forms of "ariete") is marked through graphical marks: in the first "ariete", the allograph of the "r" is the one without ligature, followed by a middle dot. In the second "ariete", "r" and "i" are joined in a ligature.

The syntax of this sentence is inconsistent. The source Priscian, Ars grammatica K.2.107.33-34 (Keil's edition) has: "In 'es' productam desinentia [feminina] tertiae declinationis uel quintae abiecta s et assumpta 'cula' faciunt diminutiua et seruant e productam, ut 'uulpes uulpecula', 'nubes nubecula', 'dies diecula', 'res recula'".
ref.w: faciunt As the subject is singular "merces", I'd correct this to "facit". The scribe probably had in mind both "merces" and "apes" as logical subjects of this verb. However, the syntactical subjectof this specific clause is "merces" alone.

lenulus Plautus' text has "lenulle", but all Priscian's manuscripts have "lenulus" (in the discussion) and "lenule" or other forms with one "l" before the final "e" (in the Plautine quote, omitted by Ursus, which is Plautus, Poenulus 470-471: "Ita ut occepi dicere, / lenulle, de illa pugna"). Ursus' source is Priscian, Ars grammatica K.2.109.6 (discussion) and K.2.109.11 (Plautine quote). Keil prints "lenullus" in both loci, but in the apparatus for K.2.109.6 he notes that Priscian's witnesses PBDHrglk have "lenulus", while in the apparatus for K.2.109.11 he writes "lenule DHKg lenulae K laenulae R laenule r" (see http://www.unipa.it/paolo.monella/ursus/sigla.pdf for Keil's sigla codicum). Based on a search on the PHI 5.3 corpus with Diogenes 3.2.0, the word "lenulus/lenullus" is a hapax in classical Latin, occurring only in the aforementioned Plautine passage. Perseus' Lewis-Short has lemma "lenullus" (http://www.perseus.tufts.edu), not "lenulus". I'll have to take this into account when I'll review the lemmatization.

us Scribal error: "us" for "nus", given the source Priscian, Ars grammatica K.2.109.12 "nus" and the sense of the whole passage. However, this discrepancy between the manuscipt and Priscian occurs in the same way for diminutives in "nus" (8r.a.37), in "na" (8r.b.11) and in "num" (8r.b.19), so it might be a deliberate choice by the scribe.

uerbialia The direct source, Priscian, Ars grammatica K.2.117.6 has "uerbalia". The form "uerbialia" is in Pompeius, "Commentum Artis Donati", K.5.149.1. Lewis-Short has a lemma "uerbialis, e, adf.", but reports Pompeius as the only example. Based on a search on the PHI 5.3 corpus with Diogenes 3.2.0, the adjective form "uerbialis" does never occur in classical Latin.

Probable scribal error: "quodcumque" for "quotcumque". The witnesses of Priscian bear both readings. This is Keil's apparatus note: "quotcumque] rdh quodcumque RDH q***cunque K quocunque numero HL et in litura k". Note that in Priscian's manuscript RDH, the second hand corrected "quodcumque" to "quotcumque" (see http://www.unipa.it/paolo.monella/ursus/sigla.pdf for Keil's sigla codicum).

w.note: The abbreviation "cor" for "correptus, -a, -um" is quite common, but up to this point it always had an abbreviation mark (a macron) above it. This is the first time that there is no visible abbreviation mark. Also, this is the first time that I meet a new type of abbreviation, that I encode as "omission" (omission of graphemes, without abbreviation mark): se the documentation for a full discussion on this type of abbreviation.

ref.note: This ":" grapheme has the function of a metamark inline, marking the point of the text in which the interlinear addition should be inserted. The ensuing "ł" (semicolon-like) grapheme is in interlinear position, with the function of a metamkark marking the beginning of the added text.

The rest of line 37 is left blank, though it has traces of erased text. Probably, however, the line originally had a different text, and the words "fiunt ut dulces dulcedo" were overwritten over it. Traces of a possibly erased text (of the length of about 5 graphemes) are also found at the beginning of line 38. The source, Priscian, Ars grammatica K.2.122.16-21, has: "et sciendum, quod e productam ante 'do', si a nominibus deriuantur, extremae syllabae terminationes in e conuertunt et accipiunt 'do', ut 'dulcis dulcēdo', 'acris acredo', sin a uerbis, secundarum terminationes personarum in e productam similiter uertunt et accepta 'do' faciunt dupra dictae formae deriuatiuum, ut 'intercapio intercapis intercapēdo'".

flebilis There is a macron over the "e" of "flēbilis" to mark the vowel's long quantity.

nitis There is a macron over the "i" of "sannītis" to mark the vowel's long quantity.
quiritis There is a macron over the second "i" of "quirītis" to mark the vowel's long quantity.
ceritis There is a macron over the first "i" of "cerītis" to mark the vowel's long quantity.

ceretis The sense requires the graphemes "ceritis" (alphabemes "ceritis", linguistic word "Caeritis"), as this is an example of a word with a short penultimate "i" (not "e"). Also see the source, Priscian, Ars grammatica K.2.134.5-7: "inuenitur tamen et correptam i habens paenultimam apud eundem Uirgilium: Est ingens gelidum lucus prope Caerĭtis amnem".
custotio Scribal error: "custotio" for "custodio". Compare the source Priscian, Ars grammatica K.2.134.15: "custodio custos".
dtis Scribal error: possibly the scribe meant to write "do dos dotis", so this word could be emendated to "dos". Compare the source Priscian, Ars grammatica K.2.134.16: "do dos".
sonorus There is a macron over the "o" of "sonōrus" to mark the vowel's long quantity.
ref.note: There is a macron over the first "i" of "seruīlis" and "seruīlius" to mark the vowel's long quantity.

There is a mark over each of the two "i"s of "aduentícíus". The same signs on the same position are on the words "commendatícíus" and "patrícíus". The shape of the signs sometimes looks like an acute accent mark, sometimes more like a macron. The second mark spans over both "i" and "u". The first sign marks the vowel's long quantity, but I am not sure about the meaning of the second mark, as the "i" should be short.
ref.w:
carthi
na This is possibly a scribal error for "chartina", but if so, if comes from Priscian's manuscripts. The source is Priscian, Ars grammatica K.2.136.3. Keil prints "chartina chartinacius" and notes in the apparatus: "chartina] r carthina RD", and then writes that a glossa to the "cod. Heidelb." explains: "epistola e charta quae a carpendo dicitur" (see http://www.unipa.it/paolo.monella/ursus/sigla.pdf for Keil's sigla codicum).

carthinacius Also in this case, this is possibly a scribal error for "chartinacius", coming from Priscian's manuscripts. The source is the same (Priscian, Ars grammatica K.2.136.3). Keil prints "chartinacius", which is his own emendation, while the readings of the manuscripts are "carthinatius RA carthinacius r" (see http://www.unipa.it/paolo.monella/ursus/sigla.pdf for Keil's sigla codicum).
